description.narrative:
A key goal of FSDT is to generate sustainable improvements in the livelihoods of poor households through reduced vulnerability to shocks increased incomes and employment. The purpose/outcome of FSDT is to achieve improved capacity and sustainability of the financial sector to meet the financial needs of MSMEs and poor men and women and to contribute to economic growth.
FSDTs results framework provides a clear description and logical link between the above goal, outcome, and four outputs - all with relevant and measurable indicators some of which are gender aggregated with baselines, annual targets, and assumptions. FSDTs four main outputs include (1) improved policy, institutional, legal and regulatory framework, and data gathering and dissemination for delivery of financial services; (2) enhanced market infrastructure and support services for financial service providers; (3) more and better financial services available to meet the needs of urban and rural enterprises; (4) more and better financial services available to meet the needs of poor urban and rural households and individuals. It is assessed that FSDTs activities through output 3 and 4 (micro level) will directly benefit the target group - excluded individuals, households and enterprises with better and inclusive financial services. While activities through output 1 and 2 (meso and macro level) will create an enabling environment for access to financial services, thus indirectly benefiting the target group by improving the capacity of the financial sector to deliver such services.
FSDT continuously revises the targets for various indicators when the goals under the above outputs are achieved ahead of time which is the case for most indicators. Changes in the log frame and its indicators have also occurred when new things need to be addressed and tracked or when some indicators have shown to be irrelevant or insufficient. Such changes are always done in consultation with the FSDT partners and approved through PIC.

Financial Sector Deepening Trust (FSDT) är en tanzanisk fond som stödjer utvecklingen av Tanzanias finanssektor och ökad tillgång till finansiella tjänster. FSDTs arbete bidrar till förbättrade policy-, institutions- och regleringsramverk och stärkt marknadsinfrastruktur liksom det stödjer leverantörer av finansiella tjänster. Syftet är ökad tillgång till finansiella tjänster för att möta behoven i städerna och på landsbygden; för individer, hushåll och företag. Under föregående nio år av svenskt stöd har FSDT visat på goda resultat med starkt engagemang från Bank of Tanzania, finansministeriet, industri- och handelsministeriet samt från leverantörer av finansiella tjänster.
Intressenters återkoppling visar att FSDT bidragit till att fylla en betydande lucka i det ekonomiska integrationsarbetet i Tanzania. Den FinScope-studie som genomfördes 2013 visar att det ekonomiska utanförskapet har halverats från 55,4% (2009) till 26,8% (2013). Tillgången till formella banktjänster har ökat från 9,1% till 13,9%. Samtidigt har tillgången till formella tjänster från andra institutioner än banker ökat från 6,7% till 43,9%.
Stora utmaningar återstår. En är att öka tillgången till formella tjänster ytterligare. Andra utmaningar är geografiska (83% av dem i utanförskap återfinns på landsbygden), kön (60,6% av dem i utanförskap är kvinnor) och utbildning (87,6% av dem i utanförskap har endast genomgått grundskoleutbildning eller lägre). En stor del av FSDTs strategi för 2013-2018 är inriktad på att stödja arbetet med att ta itu med dessa utmaningar.
Baserat på ovanstående utmaningar och bifogade bedömning föreslås att beslut fattas om stöd till en tredje fas av FSDT med ett totalt belopp på 60 miljoner kronor under fem år (2015-2019). Skälet är att ytterligare utnyttja positiva effekter från utvecklingen av finansiell integration. FSDTs fokus överensstämmer med den tanzaniska regeringens politik, strategier och åtaganden, Resultatstrategi för Sveriges internationella bistånd i Tanzania 2013-2019 samt med relevanta policyer.
Avtal om stöd till FSDT tecknas med ENSafrica | Tanzania (tidigare Rex Attorneys), registrerad förvaltare av Financial Sector Deepening Trust (Tanzania). Förvaltaren är en tanzanisk advokatbyrå som upphandlats och formellt godkänts att utföra alla de funktioner som en förvaltare innehar samt att ansvara för förtroenderådets (the Trustee) arbetsuppgifter och befogenheter i enlighet med FSDTs depositionsavtal (Trust Deed) daterat den 8 juni 2004, införlivat den 1 juli 2004. Förändringen föranledde ett tillägg till depositionsavtalet den 16 juli 2015. Inledningsvis utsågs Rex Attorneys till förvaltare av FSDT. Den 1 maj 2015 bildades ENSafrica | Tanzania efter en sammanslagning av Rex Attorneys och ENSafrica. Sammanslagning och namnbyte har dokumenterats och godkänts via förtroenderådets (the Trustee) registrator och meddelats FSDT och de givare som stödjer FSDT.
Insatsen utgör en förlängning av tidigare genomförd insats. FSDT erhåller också medel från andra givare. Befintligt avtal har kompletterats för att motsvara insatshanteringsregeln. Det kan dock noteras att Sida endast har rätt till återbetalning vid bedrägeri och liknande. Någon generell möjlighet till återbetalning vid allvarliga avtalsbrott har inte uppnåtts.

The Financial Sector Deepening Trust (FSDT) is a Tanzanian fond that supports the development of the financial sector and increased access to financial services in Tanzania. FSDT works to improve policy, institutional, and regulatory frameworks and to enhance market infrastructure and support services for financial service providers. The purpose is to increase financial services to meet the needs of urban and rural individuals, households, and enterprises. During the previous nine year period of Swedish support, FSDT has shown a track record of results with strong engagement with the Bank of Tanzania, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Industry and Trade, and financial service providers.
Stakeholder feedback is that without FSDT there would be a significant gap for financial inclusion work in Tanzania. The FinScope Survey 2013 shows that financial exclusion has halved from 55.4% to 26.8% between 2009 and 2013. Formal access using bank products has increased from 9.1% to 13.9% while formal access using non-bank products has also increased from 6.7% to 43.9%.
However, significant challenges remain. One is increasing the level of formal access. Other challenges include geography (83% of those excluded are in the rural areas), gender (60.6% of those excluded are female) and education (87.6% of those excluded have primary education or less). A major part of the FSDT strategy for 2013-2018 is focused on supporting efforts to address these challenges.
Based on the above challenges and attached assessment, this decision proposes support to the third phase of FSDT with a total amount of 60 MSEK for five years (2015-2019). The rationale is to further leverage positive impacts from developments in financial inclusion. FSDT’s focus is coherent with Government of Tanzania policies, strategies and commitments, as well as the Swedish Results Strategy for Cooperation with Tanzania 2013-2019, and relevant policies.
The agreement for support to FSDT is entered with ENSafrica | Tanzania (formerly Rex Attorneys) as the registered Trustee of the Financial Sector Deepening Trust (Tanzania). The Trustee is a Tanzanian law firm that was procured and formally approved to perform all the functions of a trustee and be responsible for the duties and powers of Trustees provided in the FSDT Trust Deed, dated 8th June 2004, incorporated on 1st July 2004. The change of the Trust Deed led to an amendment on 16th July 2015. From inception, Rex Attorneys was the registered Trustee of FSDT. On 1st May 2015 Rex Attorneys merged with ENSafrica and formed ENSafrica | Tanzania. The merger and change of name is documented and approved through the registrar of trusts and was communicated to FSDT and supporting donors.
The intervention is an extension of the previously completed intervention. FSDT also receives funds from other donors. The existing agreement has been supplemented to meet the contribution management rule. It may be noted that Sida is only entitled to a refund in case of fraud and similar. No general possibility of reimbursement has been reached in case of serious breach of contract.

participating-org.narrative: FSDT/Registered Trustees Financial Sector Deepening Trust

tag.narrative: 17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
8.10 - Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
8.10 - Stärka de inhemska finansinstitutens kapacitet att främja och utöka tillgången till bank- och försäkringstjänster samt finansiella tjänster för alla.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
9.c - Significantly increase access to information and communications technology and strive to provide universal and affordable access to the Internet in least developed countries by 2020.
9.c - Väsentligt ökad tillgången till informations- och kommunikationsteknik samt eftersträva allmän och ekonomiskt överkomlig tillgång till Internet i de minst utvecklade länderna senast 2020.

description.narrative:
- Current agreement Sida has supported FSDT since 2009. The embassy disbursed 3 MSEK in April 2021 which is the last payment for the existing agreement ending in June 2022. The disbursement was originally planned for the fall 2020 but was postponed following allegations of mishandlings within FSDT following a financial audit commissioned by Denmark. Consequently, FSDT and donors agreed on the set up a Joint Action Plan to improve matters on governance and organisation. Furthermore, as an input to the strategic reform of FSDT but also to the embassy's decision on a future cooperation with FSDT an evaluation was commissioned in 2021 (see more below).
- Annual report and assessment of results in 2021 Following the working approach of FSDT as a market facilitator the attribution of results is in general tricky, in particular when it comes to policy reforms and larger stakeholder processes. In the annual report for 2020-2021 a number of change processes are mentioned but it is difficult to assess what the role of FSDT was in achieving these results. For example, no real guidance is provided on what FSDT's role was in the decision of the government through BOT to provide a stimulus package to stimulate the economic growth and recovery due to COVID-19 impact. (for more information consult statement on the report UF2015/27250/DARE-419). FSDT has been recommended to review its reporting format and to better clarify its role in the different policy reform processes.
- PIC meetings and governance reform In addition to the annual report another source of information for the embassy to both assess and oversee the work of FSDT is the Project Investment committee (PIC), in which Sweden currently is a member together with Canada, Bill & Melinda Gates foundation and BoT. The governance reform process initiated in 2020 following concerns raised by DPs has taken a lot of focus and effort of FSDT under 2021. The previous programme officer (Mattias Lindström) was of the view that governance processes and content was taking up all the focus of the PIC and diverting attention from the intended role of the PIC to provide strategic guidance. By end of 2021 PIC approved key governance reform items such as a salary review and restructuring. A new chief executive officer and a new director of programmes were also appointed. The new leadership seems to be well qualified for their tasks. The change of leadership will be important change for DPs to regain their confidence in FSDT and the implementation of the new strategy. Regarding the salary review, which has been requested by Sweden since 2019 the end results of the salary review was not fully living up to expectations. The temporary reduction of about 15 % salaries in beginning of 2021 due budgetary constraints following the freezing of funding from DPs was not retained in the new salary structure. The new salaries are in general only reduced by about 10 % compared to levels from 2020. This means that FSDT salaries are still above the sector average salary bands. The benchmarking of NGOs, including by FSDT in 2021 by Sida indicated that the FSDT salaries were well above the suggested ranges. The higher salaries are in the FSDT new salary structure justified by more or less all positions having increased in level of responsibility. The embassy of Sweden questioned this approach but decided to along with other members of the PIC approving the salary scales in a PIC meeting 23 November 2021.
- New strategy approved for 2022-2026 On 13 October the PIC approved the new strategy covering the period of 2022-2026 (Dox UF2015/27250-DAR-424). The process of the new strategy has been long. After UK withdrawing as a partners 2020 a very advanced draft, that lacked the full support other DPs, was withdrawn and a new draft was developed. Compared the previous version the approved strategy has a more restrained focus. Nevertheless, the strategy identifies no less than eight opportunity areas for FSDT interventions. This includes for example areas such as access to credit, digital economy, green finance and agriculture finance. The new strategy explicitly prioritises women and youth. The primary outcomes are to provide improved policies and legal and regulatory frameworks that drive the utilisation of quality financial solutions. The strategy also aims to promote the equality, improved livelihood, and economic empowerment of women and youth, as well as to provide the improved availability of relevant financial sector infrastructures. Furthermore, input and recommendations from the Sida financed evaluation has to a large extent been taken into account in the new strategy.
- Evaluation 2021 An important additional source of information to review the performance of FSDT is the final evaluation commissioned by Sida in 2021. The purpose of the evaluation was to promote accountability and learning and help to inform FSDT and other DPs in decisions relating to the development and implementation of the next FSDT strategy. The evaluation focused on assessing the implementation of the FSDT strategy during 2016-2020 and also served as an input to the embassy's decision on a future support to FSDT (UM2021/14873/DARE).
Key recommendations/findings of the evaluation: - Project partners, especially government, ranks FSDT support as highly relevant to their needs - some concerns raised (short project timelines, insufficient funds to ensure adequate project completion - The evaluation shows that FSDT has, in particular, contributed to new or improved policies and regulations (e.g. NFIF 2 and Microfinance Act) - Other market system outcomes are also observed, especially regarding market infrastructure and new products and services although it is generally difficult or too soon - to assess uptake --Further strengthen MEL to ensure that the next strategy is implemented in a more adaptive, evidence-informed and learningoriented manner - Address any gaps in the budgeting and reporting system to keep overheads at agreed levels, ensure realistic financial planning, and promote Value for Money
The evaluation highlights areas, such as the microfinance act where FSDT is considered to have played an important role. At the same time the evaluation also reconfirms concerns that the embassy has identified since some time ago, including concerns regarding value for money, notable high overhead costs.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
